title: Employment Visualization
prompt: According to the table, draw a bar chart comparing the total civilian population and the total employed population for the years 1985, 1987, and 1989.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('employment-table02.xlsx') 
df.columns = df.iloc[2] 
df = df[3:] 
df.reset_index(drop=True, inplace=True) 
df.columns = ['Year', 'Civilian_Population', 'Labor_Force_Total',  
'Labor_Force_Percent_Pop', 'Employed_Total',  
'Employed_Percent_Pop', 'Employed_Agriculture',  
'Employed_NonAgriculture', 'Unemployed_Number',  
'Unemployed_Percent', 'Not_in_Labor_Force'] 
df_filtered = df[df['Year'].astype(str).isin(['1985', '1987', '1989'])] 
df_filtered[['Civilian_Population', 'Employed_Total']] = df_filtered[['Civilian_Population', 'Employed_Total']].apply(pd.to_numeric) 
df_filtered = df_filtered[['Year', 'Civilian_Population', 'Employed_Total']].drop_duplicates() 
df_filtered[['Civilian_Population', 'Employed_Total']] = df_filtered[['Civilian_Population', 'Employed_Total']].apply(pd.to_numeric) 
df_final = df_filtered.groupby('Year').agg({ 
'Civilian_Population': 'max', 
'Employed_Total': 'max' 
}).reset_index() 
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
x = df_final['Year'].astype(str) 
plt.bar(x, df_final['Civilian_Population'], label='Civilian Population', alpha=0.700) 
plt.bar(x, df_final['Employed_Total'], label='Employed Total', alpha=0.700) 
plt.xlabel('Year') 
plt.ylabel('Population (in thousands)') 
plt.title('Comparison of Civilian and Employed Population (1985, 1987, 1989)') 
plt.legend() 
plt.show()

import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('employment-table02.xlsx', skiprows=5) 
df.columns = [ 
"Year", 
"Civilian Noninstitutional Population", 
"Civilian Labor Force Total", 
"Civilian Labor Force % of Population", 
"Employed Total", 
"Employed % of Population", 
"Employed in Agriculture", 
"Employed in Nonagriculture", 
"Unemployed Total", 
"Unemployed % of Labor Force", 
"Not in Labor Force", 
] 
df = df[pd.to_numeric(df["Year"], errors='coerce').notnull()]

title: Employment Visualization
prompt: Please help me create a line chart to compare the trends of total employed population and total unemployed population from 1983 to 1990.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('employment-table02.xlsx', header=3) 
df.columns = df.columns.str.strip() 
df = df.rename(columns={"HOUSEHOLD DATA ANNUAL AVERAGES 2. Employment status of the civilian noninstitutional population 16 years and over by sex, 1983 to date": "Year"}) 
df['Group'] = df['Year'].apply(lambda x: 'Men' if isinstance(x, str) and 'Men' in x else ('Women' if isinstance(x, str) and 'Women' in x else None)) 
df['Year'] = pd.to_numeric(df['Year'], errors='coerce') 
df['Group'] = df['Group'].ffill() 
df_filtered_grouped = df[(df['Year'] >= 1983) & (df['Year'] <= 1990)] 
df_filtered_grouped = df_filtered_grouped[['Year', 'Group', 'Unnamed: 4', 'Unnamed: 8']] 
df_filtered_grouped.columns = ['Year', 'Group', 'Total Employed', 'Total Unemployed'] 
df_filtered_grouped['Total Employed'] = pd.to_numeric(df_filtered_grouped['Total Employed'], errors='coerce') 
df_filtered_grouped['Total Unemployed'] = pd.to_numeric(df_filtered_grouped['Total Unemployed'], errors='coerce') 
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8)) 
men_data = df_filtered_grouped[df_filtered_grouped['Group'] == 'Men'] 
plt.plot(men_data['Year'], men_data['Total Employed'], label='Employed (Men)', marker='o') 
plt.plot(men_data['Year'], men_data['Total Unemployed'], label='Unemployed (Men)', marker='o') 
women_data = df_filtered_grouped[df_filtered_grouped['Group'] == 'Women'] 
plt.plot(women_data['Year'], women_data['Total Employed'], label='Employed (Women)', marker='s') 
plt.plot(women_data['Year'], women_data['Total Unemployed'], label='Unemployed (Women)', marker='s') 
plt.xlabel('Year') 
plt.ylabel('Population (in thousands)') 
plt.title('Trends of Total Employed and Total Unemployed Population (1983-1990)') 
plt.legend() 
plt.grid(True) 
plt.show()

title: Employment Visualization
prompt: Generate a bar chart to compare the unemployment rates (percentage of the labor force unemployed) between different age groups as shown in the data.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('employment-table03.xlsx') 
df_cleaned = pd.read_excel('employment-table03.xlsx', skiprows=5) 

df_cleaned.columns = [ 
'Age Group', 
'Noninstitutional Population', 
'Labor Force Total', 
'Labor Force Percent', 
'Employed Total', 
'Employed Percent', 
'Unemployed Total', 
'Unemployed Percent', 
'Not in Labor Force', 
] 

df_filtered = df_cleaned[~df_cleaned['Age Group'].str.contains('TOTAL', na=False)] 
df_filtered = df_filtered[df_filtered['Age Group'].notna()] 

df_filtered['Unemployed Percent'] = pd.to_numeric(df_filtered['Unemployed Percent'], errors='coerce') 

plot_data = df_filtered[['Age Group', 'Unemployed Percent']].dropna() 
plot_data = plot_data.sort_values('Age Group') 

plot_data_grouped = plot_data.groupby('Age Group').mean().reset_index() 

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
plt.bar(plot_data_grouped['Age Group'], plot_data_grouped['Unemployed Percent']) 
plt.title('Unemployment Rates by Age Group') 
plt.xlabel('Age Group') 
plt.ylabel('Unemployment Rate (%)') 
plt.xticks(rotation=45) 
plt.tight_layout() 
plt.show()

title: Employment Data Analysis
prompt: Provide a concise summary of the table, including its main columns, the demographics it represents, and any noticeable trends in employment status by education level.
answer:
The table provides data on the employment status of the civilian noninstitutional population aged 25 years and over in the United States, segmented by educational attainment, sex, race, and Hispanic or Latino ethnicity. The main columns include:

Civilian noninstitutional population: The total number of individuals in each demographic group.

Civilian labor force: The number of individuals in the labor force, including both employed and unemployed.

Participation rate: The percentage of the population that is part of the labor force.

Employed: The number of individuals who are employed.

Employment-population ratio: The percentage of the population that is employed.

Unemployed: The number of individuals who are unemployed.

Unemployment rate: The percentage of the labor force that is unemployed.

The demographics represented include:

Sex: Men and Women

Race: White, Black or African American, Asian

Hispanic or Latino ethnicity: Hispanic or Latino ethnicity

Notable trends in employment status by education level include:

Higher education levels generally correlate with higher participation rates, employment-population ratios, and lower unemployment rates.

For example, individuals with a Bachelor's degree or higher have the highest employment-population ratios and the lowest unemployment rates across all demographic groups.

Conversely, those with less than a high school diploma have the lowest employment-population ratios and the highest unemployment rates.

Overall, the data suggests a strong positive relationship between educational attainment and employment outcomes.

import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('employment-table09.xlsx') 
df.columns = [ 
'Occupation', 'Total_2022', 'Total_2023', 'Men_2022', 'Men_2023', 
'Women_2022', 'Women_2023', '20_plus_Men_2022', '20_plus_Men_2023', 
'20_plus_Women_2022', '20_plus_Women_2023' 
] 
df_final = df.dropna(subset=['Occupation', 'Men_2023', 'Women_2023']) 
scatter_data = df_final[['Occupation', 'Men_2023', 'Women_2023']] 
scatter_data_sorted = scatter_data.sort_values(by='Occupation') 

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
plt.scatter(scatter_data_sorted['Men_2023'], scatter_data_sorted['Women_2023'], color='blue', alpha=0.60) 
plt.title('Relationship Between Total Employment for Men and Women in 2023')

relevant_data = df_cleaned[df_cleaned['Occupation'].str.contains('Management|Business and financial|Management, professional', na=False)]

)

'Age and Sex',

title: Injuries Visualization
prompt: Create a bar chart to compare the total fatalities for 'Wage and Salary' workers and 'Self-employed' workers across the event categories 'Transportation Incidents' and 'Falls, Slips, Trips.'
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('injuries-table04.xlsx') 
df_cleaned = pd.read_excel('injuries-table04.xlsx', skiprows=4) 
df_cleaned.columns = [ 
'Worker_Type', 
'Total_Fatalities', 
'Transportation_Incidents', 
'Violence', 
'Contact_With_Objects', 
'Falls_Slips_Trips', 
'Harmful_Substances', 
'Fires_Explosions', 
] 
filtered_data = df_cleaned[df_cleaned['Worker_Type'].str.contains('Wage and salary|Self-employed', na=False, case=False)] 
plot_data = filtered_data[['Worker_Type', 'Transportation_Incidents', 'Falls_Slips_Trips']] 
plot_data.iloc[:, 1:] = plot_data.iloc[:, 1:].apply(pd.to_numeric, errors='coerce') 
plot_data.reset_index(drop=True, inplace=True) 

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

plot_data_valid = plot_data.dropna().iloc[:2] 
worker_types = plot_data_valid['Worker_Type'].str.split('(', expand=True)[0].str.strip() 
transportation = plot_data_valid['Transportation_Incidents'] 
falls_slips_trips = plot_data_valid['Falls_Slips_Trips'] 

x = worker_types 
width = 0.35 

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6)) 
ax.bar(x, transportation, width, label='Transportation Incidents') 
ax.bar(x, falls_slips_trips, width, bottom=transportation, label='Falls, Slips, Trips') 

ax.set_xlabel('Worker Type') 
ax.set_ylabel('Number of Fatalities') 
ax.set_title('Total Fatalities by Worker Type and Event Category (2022)') 
ax.legend() 

plt.show()

import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('activitytime-table04.xlsx') 
 
# Extract relevant data 
data = { 
 	 'Category': ['Both spouses work full time', 'Mother employed part time and father employed full time', 'Mother not employed and father employed full time'], 
 	 'Own household children under 18': [0.62, 1.40, 2.44], 
 	 'Own household children, youngest under 6': [0.59, 1.15, 2.29], 
 	 'Own household children 6-17, none younger': [0.64, 1.61, 2.67] 
} 
 
# Create DataFrame 
df_plot = pd.DataFrame(data) 
 
# Plotting 
df_plot.set_index('Category').plot(kind='bar', rot=45) 
plt.xlabel('Employment Status') 
plt.ylabel('Difference in Time Spent (hours)') 
plt.title('Differences in Time Spent on Household Activities') 
plt.legend(title='Age of Youngest Child') 
plt.tight_layout() 
plt.show()

import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('society-table84.xlsx', header=1) 

df.columns = ['Visa Type', '2005', '2006', '2007', '2008', '2009', '2010', '2011', '2012', '2013', '2014'] 

high_value_data = df.loc[df['Visa Type'] == 'High value', ['2008', '2009', '2010', '2011', '2012', '2013', '2014']] 
high_value_data = high_value_data.apply(pd.to_numeric, errors='coerce').transpose().reset_index() 
high_value_data.columns = ['Year', 'High Value Visas'] 
high_value_data['Year'] = high_value_data['Year'].astype(int) 

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
plt.plot(high_value_data['Year'], high_value_data['High Value Visas'], marker='o', label='High Value Visas', color='b') 
plt.title('Trend in High Value Visas (2008-2014)', fontsize=16) 
plt.xlabel('Year', fontsize=14) 
plt.ylabel('Number of High Value Visas', fontsize=14) 
plt.grid(True) 
plt.legend() 
plt.tight_layout() 
plt.show()

import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('economy-table08.xlsx', header=5) 
df = df[['Year', 'Total bankruptcies [note 8]']].dropna() 
df['Total bankruptcies [note 8]'] = pd.to_numeric(df['Total bankruptcies [note 8]'], errors='coerce') 
df_filtered = df[(df['Year'] >= '2012') & (df['Year'] <= '2016') &(df['Quarter'] == '')] 

plt.plot(df_filtered['Year'], df_filtered['Total bankruptcies [note 8]'], marker='o') 
plt.xlabel('Year') 
plt.ylabel('Total Bankruptcies') 
plt.title('Trend of Total Bankruptcies (2012-2016)') 
plt.grid() 
plt.show()

 plt.show()

import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('environment-table07.xlsx', header=6) 
filtered_data = df[df['Year'].between(2005, 2009)][['Year', '50 or less']] 
filtered_data['50 or less'] = filtered_data['50 or less'].astype(int) 
plt.plot(filtered_data['Year'], filtered_data['50 or less'], marker='o', linestyle='-') 
plt.xlabel('Year') 
plt.ylabel('Number of Dwellings (50 or less)') 
plt.title('Trend in Number of Dwellings (50 or less) from 2005 to 2009') 
plt.grid(True) 
plt.show()

title: Environment Visualization
prompt: Create a pie chart showing the percentage distribution of dwellings across the “50 or less,” “51 to 100,” and “101 to 150” categories for the year 2009.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('environment-table07.xlsx', header=6) 
filtered_data = df[df['Year'] == 2009][['50 or less', '51 to 100', '101 to 150']].astype(int) 
values = filtered_data.iloc[0].values 
labels = ['50 or less', '51 to 100', '101 to 150'] 
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) 
plt.pie(values, labels=labels, autopct='%1.10f%%', startangle=140) 
plt.title('Percentage Distribution of Dwellings in 2009') 
plt.show()

title: Employment Visualization
prompt: Draw a line chart showing the trend of employment in “Advertising” and “Architecture” sub-sectors from 2005 to 2009 across all regions.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('employment-table30.xlsx',header=13) 
df = df[df['Sub-sector'].isin(['Advertising', 'Architecture'])] 
df = df.melt(id_vars='Sub-sector', var_name='Year', value_name='Employment') 
df['Year'] = df['Year'].astype(str).str.extract(r'(\d{4})').astype(float)
df['Employment'] = pd.to_numeric(df['Employment'], errors='coerce') 
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
for sub_sector in df['Sub-sector'].unique(): 
 	    sub_df = df[df['Sub-sector'] == sub_sector] 
    plt.plot(sub_df['Year'], sub_df['Employment'], marker='o', label=sub_sector) 
plt.xlabel('Year') 
plt.ylabel('Employment') 
plt.title('Trend of Employment in Advertising and Architecture (2005-2009)') 
plt.legend() 
plt.grid(True) 
plt.tight_layout() 
plt.show()

title: Health Visualization
prompt: Generate a bar chart comparing the scores of all categories in the year 2012-13.
answer:
python 
 import pandas as pd 
 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
 df = pd.read_excel('health-table09.xlsx') 
 categories = ['Access & waiting', 'Safe, high quality, coordinated care', 'Better information, more choice', 'Building closer relationships', 'Clean, friendly, comfortable place to be', 'Overall patient experience score'] 
 scores = [84.30, 65.38, 68.21, 84.59, 79.83, 76.46]

 plt.title('Scores of All Categories in 2012-13')

 plt.ylabel('Score') 
 plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right') 
 plt.tight_layout() 
 plt.show()

title: Economy Visualization
prompt: For each amenity type, create a bar chart to display the number of towers offering that amenity. Ensure the chart distinguishes between amenity types.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('economy-table50.xlsx',header=1) 
df['Amenity Type'] = df['Amenity Type'] 
df = df.fillna(0) 
amenity_counts = df.set_index('Amenity Type').sum(axis=1) 

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
amenity_counts.sort_index().plot(kind='bar', color='skyblue', edgecolor='black') 
plt.title('Number of Towers Offering Each Amenity') 
plt.xlabel('Amenity Type') 
plt.ylabel('Number of Towers') 
plt.xticks(rotation=45) 
plt.tight_layout() 
plt.show()

answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

df = pd.read_excel('labor-table02.xlsx',header=3) 
df['Expected Time to Complete'] = pd.to_numeric(df['Expected Time to Complete'].str.replace('hours', '').str.replace('days', '').str.strip(), errors='coerce') 
df = df.dropna(subset=['Expected Time to Complete', 'Job Assigning Date']) 

plt.scatter(df['Expected Time to Complete'], df['Job Assigning Date']) 
plt.xlabel('Expected Time to Complete') 
plt.ylabel('Qty') 
plt.title('Scatter Plot: Expected Time to Complete vs Job Assigning Date') 
plt.show()

title: Manufacture Visualization
prompt: Please help me draw a bar chart to illustrate the comparison of the maximum resolution for each camera in the table.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
 df = pd.read_excel('manufacture-table07.xlsx') 
 cameras = ['E-M1', 'E-M10', 'E-M1X', 'E-M5', 'Fake'] 
 max_resolution = ['4,608 x 3,456', '4,608 x 3,456', '5,184 x 3,888', '4,608 x 3,456', '4,608 x 3,456'] 
 res_values = [4608*3456, 4608*3456, 5184*3888, 4608*3456, 4608*3456] 
 plt.bar(cameras, res_values, color='skyblue') 
 plt.title('Maximum Resolution Comparison') 
 plt.xlabel('Cameras') 
 plt.ylabel('Resolution (in pixels)') 
 plt.show()

title: Manufacture Data Analysis
prompt: Can you summarize the table, highlighting the key specifications of each camera and any notable trends regarding sensor size and autofocus technology?
answer: The table provides specifications for five mirrorless cameras (E-M1, E-M10, E-M1X, E-M5, Fake). All cameras use CMOS sensors with an effective pixel count of 16 MP (except for the E-M1X, which has 20 MP). The cameras share similar autofocus technology (contrast detection), and all feature image stabilization. The table also shows a slight variation in max resolution and number of focus points, with the E-M1X having the highest focus points (121) and resolution (5,184 x 3,888). Digital zoom is available on some models, and all cameras use electronic viewfinders. There are no significant variations in sensor size, and autofocus is consistent across all models.

title: Health Visualization
prompt: Using the table, create a line chart to show the trend of total calories consumed per day over the recorded dates.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
 df = pd.read_excel('health-table14.xlsx') 
 dates = ['Mar 02', 'Mar 03', 'Mar 04'] 
 calories = [2800, 810, 6180] 
 plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6)) 
 plt.plot(dates, calories, marker='o', linestyle='-', color='b') 
 plt.title('Trend of Total Calories Consumed Per Day') 
 plt.xlabel('Date') 
 plt.ylabel('Total Calories') 
 plt.grid(True) 
 plt.show()

title: Sport Visualization
prompt: Using the table, generate a pie chart illustrating the proportion of total points contributed by the top 5 players.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('sport-table11.xlsx') 
 
df_top_5 = df[df['Place'].apply(pd.to_numeric, errors='coerce') <= 5] 
 
top_5_names = df_top_5['Name'] 
top_5_points = df_top_5['Points'] 
 
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 8)) 
plt.pie(top_5_points, labels=top_5_names, autopct='%1.10f%%', startangle=140) 
plt.title('Proportion of Total Points by Top 5 Players') 
plt.show()

prompt: Draw a scatter plot to examine the relationship between forecasted levy amounts and the alphabetical order of local authorities.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
df = pd.read_excel('environment-table11.xlsx') 
authorities = ['Bradford Metropolitan Council', 'City of York Council', 'Craven District Council', 'Harrogate Borough Council', 'Leeds City Council', 'Selby District Council'] 
forecasted_levies = [7229.00, 249154.00, 12408.00, 39500.00, 8075.00, 33352.00] 
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
plt.scatter(authorities, forecasted_levies, color='blue') 
plt.xlabel('Local Authorities (Alphabetical Order)') 
plt.ylabel('Forecasted Levy Amounts') 
plt.title('Scatter Plot of Forecasted Levy Amounts by Local Authorities') 
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right') 
plt.tight_layout() 
plt.show()

title: Environment Visualization
prompt: Based on the table, draw a linear chart comparing the time immobile of Control group treated with Vehicle with that of Control group treated with Fluoxetine.
answer:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
df = pd.read_excel('environment-table40.xlsx')
control_vehicle = df[(df['Group'] == 'Control') & (df['Treatment'] == 'Vehicle')]['Time Immobile (s)'].sort_values().reset_index(drop=True)
control_fluoxetine = df[(df['Group'] == 'Control') & (df['Treatment'] == 'Fluoxetine')]['Time Immobile (s)'].sort_values().reset_index(drop=True)
comparison_df = pd.DataFrame({'Control_Vehicle': control_vehicle, 'Control_Fluoxetine': control_fluoxetine})
comparison_df.plot(kind='line', marker='o')
plt.xlabel('Group')
plt.ylabel('Time Immobile (s)')
plt.title('Comparison of Time Immobile Between Control Groups Treated with Vehicle and Fluoxetine')
plt.xticks(ticks=range(len(control_vehicle)), labels=range(len(control_vehicle)))
plt.show()

title: Science Visualization
prompt: Create a scatter plot to explore the potential correlation between the estrous cycle number and the variance for luminal cells. Include a trendline to indicate the direction of the relationship.
answer:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
df = pd.read_excel('science-table27.xlsx', skiprows=1, header=[0, 1])
luminal_cycle_no = df['luminal']['estrous cycle no.'].dropna().sort_values()
luminal_variance = df.loc[luminal_cycle_no.index, ('luminal', 'variance')]
plt.scatter(luminal_cycle_no, luminal_variance, label='Luminal Data Points')
z = np.polyfit(luminal_cycle_no, luminal_variance, 1)
p = np.poly1d(z)
plt.plot(luminal_cycle_no, p(luminal_cycle_no), color='red', linestyle='--', label='Luminal Trendline')
plt.xlabel('Estrous Cycle Number')
plt.ylabel('Variance')
plt.title('Scatter Plot of Estrous Cycle Number vs Variance for Luminal Cells')
plt.legend()
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
df = pd.read_excel('science-table30.xlsx', skiprows=1, header=[0, 1])
luminal_cycle_no = df['luminal']['estrous cycle no.'].dropna().sort_values()
luminal_average = df.loc[luminal_cycle_no.index, ('luminal', 'average')]
plt.scatter(luminal_cycle_no, luminal_average, label='Luminal Data Points')
z = np.polyfit(luminal_cycle_no, luminal_average, 1)
p = np.poly1d(z)
plt.plot(luminal_cycle_no, p(luminal_cycle_no), color="red", linestyle='--', label='Luminal Trendline')
plt.xlabel('Estrous Cycle Number')
plt.ylabel('Average')
plt.title('Scatter Plot of Estrous Cycle Number vs Average for Luminal Cells')
plt.legend()
plt.show()

replicate3_data = df[('Experiment 1', 'Replicate 3', 'No. of infected DCs')][:30]
data_to_plot = pd.concat([replicate1_data, replicate2_data, replicate3_data], axis=1)
data_to_plot.columns = ['Replicate 1', 'Replicate 2', 'Replicate 3']

plt.show()

title: Health Visualization
prompt: Based on the table, draw a bar chart comparing the No. of intracellular amastgotes for each replicate in experiment 1.
answer:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
df = pd.read_excel('health-table37.xlsx', header=[2, 3, 4])
replicate1_data = df[('Experiment 1', 'Replicate 1', 'No. of intracellular amastgotes')][:30]
replicate2_data = df[('Experiment 1', 'Replicate 2', 'No. of intracellular amastgotes')][:30]
replicate3_data = df[('Experiment 1', 'Replicate 3', 'No. of intracellular amastgotes')][:30]
data_to_plot = pd.concat([replicate1_data, replicate2_data, replicate3_data], axis=1)
data_to_plot.columns = ['Replicate 1', 'Replicate 2', 'Replicate 3']
data_to_plot.index = range(1, len(data_to_plot) + 1)
data_to_plot.plot(kind='bar')
plt.xlabel('Observation Index')
plt.ylabel('No. of intracellular amastgotes')
plt.title('Comparison of No. of intracellular amastgotes for Each Replicate in Experiment 1')
plt.show()

ABS Plastic shows lower average recovery values, indicating higher effectiveness against organisms like Escherichia coli, while Glass and Stainless Steel exhibit higher recovery, suggesting lesser effectiveness. title: Health Visualization
prompt: Generate a scatter plot showing the relationship between “Log10 Recovery (Inoculation Control)” and “Log10 Recovery (Test Sample)”, with points colored by “Test Material”.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
 df = pd.read_excel('health-table16.xlsx') 
 df['Test Material'] = df['Test Material'].str.strip() 
 test_materials = df['Test Material'].dropna().unique() 
 colors = plt.cm.tab10(range(len(test_materials))) 
 color_map = dict(zip(test_materials, colors)) 
 plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) 
 for material in test_materials: 
 	 subset = df[df['Test Material'] == material] 
 	 plt.scatter(subset['Log10 Recovery (Inoculation Control)'], subset['Log10 Recovery (Test Sample)'], label=material, color=color_map[material]) 
 plt.xlabel('Log10 Recovery (Inoculation Control)') 
 plt.ylabel('Log10 Recovery (Test Sample)') 
 plt.title('Scatter Plot of Log10 Recovery by Test Material') 
 plt.legend(title='Test Material') 
 plt.show()

Key columns include production metrics, separated into commercial and farm-level outputs, as well as imports, exports, and beginning and ending stocks to track inventory changes. Additionally, it provides data on total disappearance, which reflects overall consumption, and per capita disappearance, presented in various weight formats such as carcass, retail, and boneless retail weight. The data is presented quarterly across multiple years, highlighting trends influenced by seasonal or economic factors. Initial observations reveal fluctuations in production, supply, and trade metrics, with corresponding impacts on disappearance figures and per capita consumption rates.

earnings = df.iloc[4:33, 2].astype(int)
plt.plot(years, earnings, marker='o')
plt.title('Median Earnings for Men with Less Than a High School Diploma (1985-2013)')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Median Earnings (in constant 2016 dollars)')
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

answer:
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df = pd.read_excel('religion-table05.xlsx', sheet_name='Table 10', header=1)
df.columns = df.columns.str.strip()

years = [2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018]
percentages = []

for year in years:
	row = df[df.iloc[:, 0] == year].index[0]
	percentage = df.iloc[row + 7, 13]
	percentages.append(percentage)

plt.bar(years, percentages, color='blue')
plt.xlabel('Year')
plt.ylabel('Percentage')
plt.title('Percentage of Muslims Employed in Distribution, Hotels, and Restaurants Sector (2012-2018)')
plt.xticks(years)
plt.show()

title: Manufacture Visualization
prompt: Using the table, draw a line chart to illustrate the trend of RPH for Queue P0003 across all 7 weeks.
answer:
import pandas as pd 
 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 
 df = pd.read_excel('manufacture-table21.xlsx') 
 weeks = ['Week 1', 'Week 2', 'Week 3', 'Week 4', 'Week 5', 'Week 6', 'Week 7'] 
 rph_values = [0.41, 0.42, 0.43, 0.44, 0.45, 0.46, 0.47] 
 plt.plot(weeks, rph_values, marker='o', linestyle='-', color='blue', label='Queue P0003 RPH') 
 plt.title('Trend of RPH for Queue P0003') 
 plt.xlabel('Weeks') 
 plt.ylabel('RPH') 
 plt.grid(True) 
 plt.legend() 
 plt.show()

title: Manufacture Data Analysis
prompt: Can you provide a detailed summary of the table, explaining the key components such as RPH, Quality, and Weeks, and highlighting any observed patterns or trends?

Quality percentages steadily improve for P0003 and P0004, while P0001 and P0002 maintain consistently high levels.
